results.title: China to Launch 3 Astronauts to New Space Station: How to Watch
results.abstract: The crew will set off from a secretive desert launch center to rendezvous with fellow astronauts aboard Tiangong, the country’s newly completed outpost in orbit.

results.title: Whole Foods to Stop Buying Maine Lobster Amid Risk to Endangered Whales
results.abstract: Maine’s political leaders criticized the decision, which was based on assessments by two conservation groups that have raised concerns that North Atlantic right whales have become entangled in the ropes used to fish for lobster.

results.title: Monkeypox Has a New Name: Mpox
results.abstract: Health experts said the old nomenclature was imprecise, played into racist stereotypes and fueled stigmatization, making it harder to contain the most recent outbreaks.

results.title: Organ Donations Rise Around Motorcycle Rallies
results.abstract: A new study suggests a link between the large gatherings and a slightly higher number of transplants after traffic crashes.

multimedia.caption: Motorcycle enthusiasts attend the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally in Sturgis, S.D., in 2021. A new study links such rallies to increased numbers of organ donors.

results.title: Roman Coins Thought for Centuries to Be Fakes Get a Fresh Appraisal
results.abstract: New research suggests that the gold coins, which were found in 1713 and long dismissed as forgeries, may be authentic.

multimedia.caption: Long considered fake, gold coins like this one bearing the image of a mysterious third-century figure named Sponsian may be authentic, researchers say.

results.title: As Gen X and Boomers Age, They Confront Living Alone
results.abstract: More older Americans are living by themselves than ever before. That shift presents issues on housing, health care and personal finance.
results.byline: By Dana Goldstein and Robert Gebeloff

results.title: The Worlds of the ‘Remarkably Prescient’ Octavia Butler
results.abstract: A new interactive article in The Times immerses readers in significant locations and moments from the life of the pioneering science fiction writer.

results.title: Meet the Man on a Mission to Expose Sneaky Price Increases
results.abstract: Edgar Dworsky has become the go-to expert on “shrinkflation,” when products or packaging are manipulated so people get less for their money.

results.abstract: One year after the variant’s discovery, virologists are still scrambling to keep up with Omicron’s rapid evolution.

results.title: Frederick P. Brooks Jr., Computer Design Innovator, Dies at 91
results.abstract: He was a lead designer of the computers that cemented IBM’s dominance for decades. He later wrote a book on software engineering that became a quirky classic.

multimedia.caption: The computer scientist Frederick P. Brooks Jr. in 2014 with a first-generation Apple Macintosh computer. Dr. Brooks, a technical leader at IBM in the 1960s, admired the design of the Mac, which he said was “right in so many ways.”
multimedia.copyright: Steve Exum, via U.N.C. Department of Computer Science

results.title: Could I Survive the ‘Quietest Place on Earth’?

results.title: Flu and R.S.V. Hit the Holidays, Heightening Demand for Antibiotics and Antivirals
results.abstract: An intense early flu season, coupled with a pediatric rise in respiratory illnesses, has left families frantically searching for medicines that are in short supply.

results.title: As Dinosaur Fossils Fetch Millions, There’s Many a Bone to Pick
results.abstract: Fossils are a multimillion-dollar business, bringing legal disputes, nondisclosure agreements and trademarks to the world of paleontology.
results.byline: By Julia Jacobs and Zachary Small
org_facet: Black Hills Institute of Geological Research Inc

results.title: Earth Now Has 8 Billion Humans. This Man Wishes There Were None.
results.abstract: For the sake of the planet, Les Knight, the founder of the Voluntary Human Extinction movement, has spent decades pushing one message: “May we live long and die out.”

results.title: A Year After the Omicron Surge, Officials See a Reduced Covid Threat This Winter
results.abstract: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said the administration was optimistic that “we’re not going to see a repeat of what we saw last year,” when the Omicron variant swept through the country.

results.title: Climate Change Is Threatening Hawaii’s Coral Reefs. So They Called the Insurance Guy.
results.abstract: If worsening coastal storms damage the reefs, the Nature Conservancy will get a payout and use the money to repair the coral — work that state officials can’t afford to do.

results.title: With Anxiety on the Rise, Some Children Try ‘Exposure Therapy’
results.abstract: A gold-standard treatment for phobias and anxieties encourages young people to follow an old and simple dictum: Face your fears.
results.byline: By Virginia Hughes and Desiree Rios

multimedia.caption: Nicole Burlingame preparing a warm hot dog for her son, Jason, to try to eat during an exposure session in their kitchen. Jason was afraid of choking while eating.

results.title: Inside the Saudi Strategy to Keep the World Hooked on Oil
results.abstract: The kingdom is working to keep fossil fuels at the center of the world economy for decades to come by lobbying, funding research and using its diplomatic muscle to obstruct climate action.

results.title: Jay Pasachoff, Who Pursued Eclipses Across the Globe, Dies at 79
results.abstract: An astronomer at Williams College, he probably saw more solar eclipses than any other human in history.

multimedia.caption: Jay M. Pasachoff in 2017. He made the study of solar eclipses his life’s work, spending up to three years before an eclipse preparing equipment, lining up grants, arranging travel and planning for contingencies.
multimedia.copyright: Nathaniel Brooks for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Jay M. Pasachoff in 2017. He made the study of solar eclipses his life’s work, spending up to three years before an eclipse preparing equipment, lining up grants, arranging travel and planning for contingencies.

results.title: U.N. Climate Talks End With a Deal to Pay Poor Nations for Damage
results.abstract: Nations reached a landmark deal to compensate developing nations for climate harm. But some leaders said the summit didn’t go far enough in addressing the root causes of global warming.
results.byline: By Brad Plumer, Max Bearak, Lisa Friedman and Jenny Gross
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

results.title: ¿Los árboles hablan bajo tierra? Para los científicos, eso está en disputa
results.abstract: Desde Ted Lasso hasta las charlas TED, la teoría de la “red de los bosques” está en todas partes, y algunos científicos sostienen que es exagerada y no está probada.
